required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on May 29, 2018
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: A Study of Ketamine in Patients With Treatment-resistant Depression
clinical_study.official_title: A Double-blind, Randomized, Placebo-controlled, Parallel Group, Dose Frequency Study of Ketamine in Subjects With Treatment-resistant Depression

brief_summary.textblock: The purpose of this study is to explore the optimal dose frequency of ketamine in patients with treatment-resistant depression (TRD).

detailed_description.textblock: This is a double-blind (patients and study personnel do not know the identity of the administered treatments), randomized (the drug is assigned by chance), placebo-controlled (placebo is a substance that appears identical to the treatment and has no active ingredients), parallel arm study (each group of patients will be treated at the same time). The study will consist of a screening phase of up to 4 weeks, a 4-week double-blind treatment phase (Day 1 to Day 29), and a 3-week post treatment (follow up) phase. In the double-blind phase, patients will receive over 4 weeks either intravenous (IV) infusions of placebo (2 or 3 times weekly) or IV infusions of ketamine (2 or 3 times weekly). The total study duration for each patient will be a maximum of 13 weeks.

primary_outcome.measure: Change in Montgomery-Asberg Depression Rating Scale (MADRS) Total Score From Baseline to Day 15
primary_outcome.description: The MADRS is a clinician-rated scale designed to measure depression severity and detects changes due to antidepressant treatment. The test consists of 10 items, each of which is scored from 0 (item not present or normal) to 6 (severe or continuous presence of the symptoms), for a total score of 60. Higher scores represent a more severe condition.

secondary_outcome.measure: Change in Montgomery-Asberg Depression Rating Scale (MADRS) Total Score From Baseline to Day 29
secondary_outcome.description: The MADRS is a clinician-rated scale designed to measure depression severity and detects changes due to antidepressant treatment. The test consists of 10 items, each of which is scored from 0 (item not present or normal) to 6 (severe or continuous presence of the symptoms), for a total score of 60. Higher scores represent a more severe condition.

secondary_outcome.measure: Number of Responders Based on Montgomery-Asberg Depression Rating Scale (MADRS) Total Score
secondary_outcome.description: Participants with a reduction in the MADRS total score of greater than or equal to (>=) 50 percent from baseline were defined as responders. The MADRS is a clinician-rated scale designed to measure depression severity and detects changes due to antidepressant treatment. The test consists of 10 items, each of which is scored from 0 (item not present or normal) to 6 (severe or continuous presence of the symptoms), for a total score of 60. Higher scores represent a more severe condition.

secondary_outcome.measure: Number of Remitters Based on Montgomery-Asberg Depression Rating Scale (MADRS) Total Score
secondary_outcome.description: Participants who had a MADRS total score of less than or equal to (<=) 10 were considered remitters. The MADRS is a clinician-rated scale designed to measure depression severity and detects changes due to antidepressant treatment. The test consists of 10 items, each of which is scored from 0 (item not present or normal) to 6 (severe or continuous presence of the symptoms), for a total score of 60. Higher scores represent a more severe condition.

secondary_outcome.measure: Number of Sustained Responders Based on Montgomery-Asberg Depression Rating Scale (MADRS) Total Score
secondary_outcome.description: Sustained response on Day 15 was defined as achieving an onset of antidepressant response within the first week that is maintained to the end of study Day 15. The MADRS is a clinician-rated scale designed to measure depression severity and detects changes due to antidepressant treatment. The test consists of 10 items, each of which is scored from 0 (item not present or normal) to 6 (severe or continuous presence of the symptoms), for a total score of 60. Higher scores represent a more severe condition.

secondary_outcome.measure: Change in Clinical Global Impression-Severity (CGI-S) Score From Baseline to Endpoint (Day 29)
secondary_outcome.description: The CGI-S was used to rate the severity of the participants illness at the time of assessment, relative to the clinician's past experience with participants who had the same diagnosis and improvement with treatment. Considering total clinical experience, a participant was assessed on severity of mental illness at the time of rating according to: 0= not assessed; 1=normal (not at all ill); 2=borderline mentally ill; 3=mildly ill; 4=moderately ill; 5=markedly ill; 6=severely ill; 7=among the most extremely ill participants.

secondary_outcome.measure: Clinical Global Impression of Improvement (CGI-I) Score at Endpoint of Double Blind Phase
secondary_outcome.description: The CGI-I is a 7-point scale that was used to assess how much the participants illness was improved or worsened relative to a baseline state at the beginning of the intervention and rated as: 0= not assessed; 1=very much improved; 2=much improved; 3=minimally improved; 4=no change; 5=minimally worse; 6=much worse; 7=very much worse.

secondary_outcome.measure: Change in Patient Global Impression-Severity (PGI-S) Score From Baseline to Endpoint (Day 29)
secondary_outcome.description: The PGI-S is an 11-point (0 to 10) scale that required the participant to rate the severity of their illness at the time of assessment, relative to the participants past experience. Considering their total experience, the participant was to assess the severity of their depression illness at the time of rating as none, mild, moderate or severe. The scale is rated as, 0=very well and 10=very poor.

secondary_outcome.measure: Patient Global Impression-Change (PGI-C) Score at Endpoint of Double Blind Phase
secondary_outcome.description: The PGI-C is a 7-point scale that required the subject to assess how much their illness had improved or worsened relative to a baseline state at the beginning of the intervention. The response options were: very much improved; much improved; improved (just enough to make a difference); no change; worse (just enough to make a difference); much worse; or very much worse. The scale is rated as, 1=very much improved and 7=very much worse.

secondary_outcome.measure: Maximum Observed Plasma Concentration (Cmax) of Ketamine
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Pre-infusion, 20, 40 (End of the Infusion), 45, 50, 60, 90, 120, 180, 240 and 360 minutes post-infusion on Day 1 and Day 15
secondary_outcome.description: The Cmax is the maximum observed plasma concentration of drug.

secondary_outcome.measure: Time to Reach Maximum Observed Plasma Concentration (Tmax) of Ketamine
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Pre-infusion, 20, 40 (End of the Infusion), 45, 50, 60, 90, 120, 180, 240 and 360 minutes post-infusion on Day 1 and Day 15
secondary_outcome.description: The Tmax is defined as actual sampling time to reach maximum observed drug concentration.

secondary_outcome.measure: Area Under the Plasma Concentration-Time Curve From Time Zero to Last Quantifiable Time (AUC[0-last])
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Pre-infusion, 20, 40 (End of the Infusion), 45, 50, 60, 90, 120, 180, 240 and 360 minutes post-infusion on Day 1 and Day 15
secondary_outcome.description: The AUC(0-last) is the area under the plasma concentration-time curve from time zero to last quantifiable time.

secondary_outcome.measure: Area Under the Plasma Concentration-Time Curve From Time Zero to Infinite Time (AUC[0-infinity])
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Pre-infusion, 20, 40 (End of the Infusion), 45, 50, 60, 90, 120, 180, 240 and 360 minutes post-infusion on Day 1 and Day 15
secondary_outcome.description: The AUC (0-infinity) is the area under the plasma concentration-time curve from time zero to infinite time, calculated as the sum of AUC (last) and C(last)/lambda(z); wherein AUC(last) is area under the plasma concentration-time curve from time zero to last quantifiable time, C(last) is the last observed quantifiable concentration, and lambda(z) is elimination rate constant.

secondary_outcome.time_frame: Pre-infusion, 20, 40 (End of the Infusion), 45, 50, 60, 90, 120, 180, 240 and 360 minutes post-infusion on Day 1 and Day 15
secondary_outcome.description: The CL is a quantitative measure of the rate at which a drug substance is removed from the body.

secondary_outcome.measure: Volume of Distribution at Steady-State (Vss) of Ketamine
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Pre-infusion, 20, 40 (End of the Infusion), 45, 50, 60, 90, 120, 180, 240 and 360 minutes post-infusion on Day 1 and Day 15
secondary_outcome.description: The Vss is defined as the theoretical volume in which the total amount of drug would need to be uniformly distributed to produce the desired serum concentration of ketamine at steady state.

secondary_outcome.time_frame: Pre-infusion, 20, 40 (End of the Infusion), 45, 50, 60, 90, 120, 180, 240 and 360 minutes post-infusion on Day 1 and Day 15
secondary_outcome.description: The elimination half-life (t1/2) is the time measured for the plasma concentration to decrease by 1 half to its original concentration. It is associated with the terminal slope of the semi logarithmic drug concentration-time curve, and is calculated as 0.693/lambda(z).

intervention.description: Form= intravenous infusion, route= intravenous (IV) use. IV infusions of placebo 2 times weekly or IV infusions of placebo 3 times weekly.

Type= exact number, unit= mg/kg, number= 0.5, form= intravenous infusion, route= intravenous (IV) use. IV infusions of ketamine 0.50 mg/kg, 2 times weekly or IV infusions of ketamine 0.50 mg/kg, 3 times weekly.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Be medically stable on the basis of clinical laboratory tests performed at screening
- Meet diagnostic criteria for recurrent major depressive disorder (MDD), without psychotic features
- Have a history of inadequate response, ie treatment was not successful, to at least 1 antidepressant
- Have an Inventory of Depressive Symptoms-Clinician rated, 30 item (IDS-C30) total score >= 40 at screening and predose at Day 1
- Inpatient or agreed to be admitted to the clinic on each dosing day
Exclusion Criteria:
- Has uncontrolled hypertension
- Has a history of, or current signs and symptoms of diseases, infections or conditions that in the opinion of the investigator, would make participation not be in the best interest (eg, compromise the well-being) of the patient or that could prevent, limit, or confound the protocol-specified assessments
- Has known allergies, hypersensitivity, or intolerance to ketamine or its excipients
- Is unable to read and understand the consent forms and patient reported outcomes, complete study-related procedures, and/or communicate with the study staff

overall_official.last_name: Janssen Research & Development, LLC Clinical Trial

participant_flow.pre_assignment_details: A total of 165 participants were screened and 68 participants were randomized into the study. Of these 68 participants randomized, 67 participants received at least 1 dose of the study agent (Intent-To-Treat analysis set).

group.title: Placebo: 2 Times Per Week
group.description: Participants received Intravenous (IV) infusion of placebo 2 times weekly for 4 weeks.

group.title: Ketamine: 2 Times Per Week
group.description: Participants received 0.50 milligram per kilogram (mg/kg) ketamine IV infusion 2 times weekly for 4 weeks.

group.title: Placebo: 3 Times Per Week
group.description: Participants received IV infusion of placebo 3 times weekly for 4 weeks.

group.title: Ketamine: 3 Times Per Week
group.description: Participants received 0.50 mg/kg ketamine IV infusion 3 times weekly for 4 weeks.

baseline.population: The Intent-To-Treat (ITT) analysis set is defined as participants who were randomized and received at least 1 dose of the study drug.

group.title: Placebo: 2 Times Per Week
group.description: Participants received Intravenous (IV) infusion of placebo 2 times weekly for 4 weeks.

group.title: Ketamine: 2 Times Per Week
group.description: Participants received 0.50 milligram per kilogram (mg/kg) ketamine IV infusion 2 times weekly for 4 weeks.

group.title: Placebo: 3 Times Per Week
group.description: Participants received IV infusion of placebo 3 times weekly for 4 weeks.

group.title: Ketamine: 3 Times Per Week
group.description: Participants received 0.50 mg/kg ketamine IV infusion 3 times weekly for 4 weeks.

group.title: Total
group.description: Total of all reporting groups

outcome.title: Change in Montgomery-Asberg Depression Rating Scale (MADRS) Total Score From Baseline to Day 15
outcome.description: The MADRS is a clinician-rated scale designed to measure depression severity and detects changes due to antidepressant treatment. The test consists of 10 items, each of which is scored from 0 (item not present or normal) to 6 (severe or continuous presence of the symptoms), for a total score of 60. Higher scores represent a more severe condition.
outcome.population: An intent-to-treat (ITT) analysis set is defined as all participants who receive at least 1 dose of study drug and have both Day 1 (baseline) and at least 1 post-baseline MADRS total score. Here,“N”(Number of Participants Analyzed) and “n” signifies those participants who were evaluable for this outcome measure and at given time point, respectively

group.description: Participants received 0.50 milligram per kilogram (mg/kg) ketamine IV infusion 2 times weekly for 4 weeks.

group.title: Placebo: 3 Times Per Week
group.description: Participants received IV infusion of placebo 3 times weekly for 4 weeks.

group.title: Ketamine: 3 Times Per Week
group.description: Participants received 0.50 mg/kg ketamine IV infusion 3 times weekly for 4 weeks.

measure.title: Patient Global Impression-Change (PGI-C) Score at Endpoint of Double Blind Phase
measure.description: The PGI-C is a 7-point scale that required the subject to assess how much their illness had improved or worsened relative to a baseline state at the beginning of the intervention. The response options were: very much improved; much improved; improved (just enough to make a difference); no change; worse (just enough to make a difference); much worse; or very much worse. The scale is rated as, 1=very much improved and 7=very much worse.
measure.population: An intent-to-treat (ITT) analysis set is defined as all participants who receive at least 1 dose of study drug and have both Day 1 (baseline) and at least 1 post-baseline MADRS total score. Here,“N”(Number of Participants Analyzed) signifies those participants who were evaluable for this outcome measure.

outcome.title: Maximum Observed Plasma Concentration (Cmax) of Ketamine
outcome.description: The Cmax is the maximum observed plasma concentration of drug.
outcome.time_frame: Pre-infusion, 20, 40 (End of the Infusion), 45, 50, 60, 90, 120, 180, 240 and 360 minutes post-infusion on Day 1 and Day 15

outcome.title: Time to Reach Maximum Observed Plasma Concentration (Tmax) of Ketamine
outcome.description: The Tmax is defined as actual sampling time to reach maximum observed drug concentration.

measure.title: Time to Reach Maximum Observed Plasma Concentration (Tmax) of Ketamine

outcome.title: Area Under the Plasma Concentration-Time Curve From Time Zero to Last Quantifiable Time (AUC[0-last])
outcome.description: The AUC(0-last) is the area under the plasma concentration-time curve from time zero to last quantifiable time.
outcome.time_frame: Pre-infusion, 20, 40 (End of the Infusion), 45, 50, 60, 90, 120, 180, 240 and 360 minutes post-infusion on Day 1 and Day 15
outcome.population: An intent-to-treat (ITT) analysis set is defined as all participants who receive at least 1 dose of study drug and have both Day 1 (baseline) and at least 1 post-baseline MADRS total score. group.title: Ketamine: 2 Times Per Week

measure.title: Area Under the Plasma Concentration-Time Curve From Time Zero to Last Quantifiable Time (AUC[0-last])
measure.description: The AUC(0-last) is the area under the plasma concentration-time curve from time zero to last quantifiable time.
measure.population: An intent-to-treat (ITT) analysis set is defined as all participants who receive at least 1 dose of study drug and have both Day 1 (baseline) and at least 1 post-baseline MADRS total score. Here,“N”(Number of Participants Analyzed) and “n” signifies those participants who were evaluable for this outcome measure and at given time point, respectively

outcome.title: Area Under the Plasma Concentration-Time Curve From Time Zero to Infinite Time (AUC[0-infinity])
outcome.description: The AUC (0-infinity) is the area under the plasma concentration-time curve from time zero to infinite time, calculated as the sum of AUC (last) and C(last)/lambda(z); wherein AUC(last) is area under the plasma concentration-time curve from time zero to last quantifiable time, C(last) is the last observed quantifiable concentration, and lambda(z) is elimination rate constant.
outcome.time_frame: Pre-infusion, 20, 40 (End of the Infusion), 45, 50, 60, 90, 120, 180, 240 and 360 minutes post-infusion on Day 1 and Day 15
outcome.population: An intent-to-treat (ITT) analysis set is defined as all participants who receive at least 1 dose of study drug and have both Day 1 (baseline) and at least 1 post-baseline MADRS total score. Here,“N”(Number of Participants Analyzed) and “n” signifies those participants who were evaluable for this outcome measure and at given time point, respectively

measure.description: The AUC (0-infinity) is the area under the plasma concentration-time curve from time zero to infinite time, calculated as the sum of AUC (last) and C(last)/lambda(z); wherein AUC(last) is area under the plasma concentration-time curve from time zero to last quantifiable time, C(last) is the last observed quantifiable concentration, and lambda(z) is elimination rate constant.
measure.population: An intent-to-treat (ITT) analysis set is defined as all participants who receive at least 1 dose of study drug and have both Day 1 (baseline) and at least 1 post-baseline MADRS total score. outcome.title: Total Systemic Clearance (CL) of Ketamine
outcome.description: The CL is a quantitative measure of the rate at which a drug substance is removed from the body.
outcome.time_frame: Pre-infusion, 20, 40 (End of the Infusion), 45, 50, 60, 90, 120, 180, 240 and 360 minutes post-infusion on Day 1 and Day 15
outcome.population: An intent-to-treat (ITT) analysis set is defined as all participants who receive at least 1 dose of study drug and have both Day 1 (baseline) and at least 1 post-baseline MADRS total score. measure.title: Total Systemic Clearance (CL) of Ketamine

outcome.title: Volume of Distribution at Steady-State (Vss) of Ketamine
outcome.description: The Vss is defined as the theoretical volume in which the total amount of drug would need to be uniformly distributed to produce the desired serum concentration of ketamine at steady state.
outcome.time_frame: Pre-infusion, 20, 40 (End of the Infusion), 45, 50, 60, 90, 120, 180, 240 and 360 minutes post-infusion on Day 1 and Day 15
outcome.population: An intent-to-treat (ITT) analysis set is defined as all participants who receive at least 1 dose of study drug and have both Day 1 (baseline) and at least 1 post-baseline MADRS total score. Here,“N”(Number of Participants Analyzed) and “n” signifies those participants who were evaluable for this outcome measure and at given time point, respectively

group.title: Ketamine: 3 Times Per Week

measure.title: Volume of Distribution at Steady-State (Vss) of Ketamine
measure.description: The Vss is defined as the theoretical volume in which the total amount of drug would need to be uniformly distributed to produce the desired serum concentration of ketamine at steady state.
measure.population: An intent-to-treat (ITT) analysis set is defined as all participants who receive at least 1 dose of study drug and have both Day 1 (baseline) and at least 1 post-baseline MADRS total score. Here,“N”(Number of Participants Analyzed) and “n” signifies those participants who were evaluable for this outcome measure and at given time point, respectively

outcome.title: Elimination Half-Life (t1/2)
outcome.description: The elimination half-life (t1/2) is the time measured for the plasma concentration to decrease by 1 half to its original concentration. It is associated with the terminal slope of the semi logarithmic drug concentration-time curve, and is calculated as 0.693/lambda(z).
outcome.time_frame: Pre-infusion, 20, 40 (End of the Infusion), 45, 50, 60, 90, 120, 180, 240 and 360 minutes post-infusion on Day 1 and Day 15
outcome.population: An intent-to-treat (ITT) analysis set is defined as all participants who receive at least 1 dose of study drug and have both Day 1 (baseline) and at least 1 post-baseline MADRS total score. Here,“N”(Number of Participants Analyzed) and “n” signifies those participants who were evaluable for this outcome measure and at given time point, respectively

certain_agreements.pi_employee: Principal Investigators are NOT employed by the organization sponsoring the study.
certain_agreements.restrictive_agreement: A copy of the manuscript must be provided to the sponsor for review at least 60 days before submission for publication or presentation. If requested in writing, such publication will be withheld for up to an additional 60 days.
